sentences.sentence: By Michael Burns and Cecile ChungTwo historic sports teams that may not be familiar to everyone are being inducted this week into the Canadian Sports Hall of Fame and will be awarded Canada's highest sporting honour, the Order of Sport.When we think of women's hockey in Canada, we may first think of Canada's Olympic team victories over the past couple of decades.
Even with those incredible achievements, they weren't the most successful women's ice hockey team in Canada.
That title goes to The Preston Rivulettes.The Preston Rivulettes raised the profile of women's ice hockey in Canada to new heights in the 1930s and still inspire us today.

From 1931 to 1940, the Rivulettes claimed 10 provincial titles in Ontario, five Eastern Canadian Championships and four national Dominion titles.Though the Rivulettes regularly drew thousands of cheering fans to their games, they faced gender-based discrimination, scarce funding and limited resources.The other team that will be honoured is the Chatham Coloured Men's baseball team.

Formed in 1932, the Chatham Coloured All-Stars challenged discriminatory perceptions of Black athletes more than a decade before Jackie Robinson broke the MLB colour barrier in 1947.The Chatham Coloured All-Stars made history in 1934 as the first Black team to win a provincial baseball championship in Ontario.

Overcoming discrimination on and off the field, they played despite the constant threat of racial violence, racist officiating and the need to travel extensively at a time when Blacks were often barred from restaurants and hotels in southern Ontario.Ferguson Jenkins Sr. was a member of the Chatham Coloured All-Stars.

His son, Ferguson Jenkins Jr., would go on to be considered by many as Canada's greatest baseball player and was inducted into Major League Baseball Hall of Fame in 1991.The Rivulettes and the Chatham Coloured All-Stars each left an indelible mark on Canadian sports history and created an inspirational legacy of excellence and perseverance.

Their athletes played and excelled in the games they loved, despite open hostility and discrimination.The Chatham all-Black All-Stars went all the way in 1934, a decade before Jackie Robinson broke baseball's colour barrier(https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/the-chatham-all-black-all-stars-went-all-the-way-in-1934-a-decade-before-jackie-robinson-broke-baseballs-colour-barrier)Inspired by a real-life story, Glory highlights the prejudice that faces women in Canadian sports(https://nationalpost.com/sponsored/entertainment-sponsored/inspired-by-a-real-life-story-glory-highlights-the-prejudice-that-faces-women-in-canadian-sports)They remind us of the enduring power of sport and its ability to help us to overcome obstacles in the face of incredible odds.
They also remind us that in 2022 the fight against discrimination and sexism is not over.

The challenges the Preston Rivulettes and the Chatham Coloured All-Stars faced underscore the need to offer respect to everyone and embrace diversity, and to break down the barriers that still exist in sport so that everyone has an opportunity to be the best version of themself.When these two teams are finally inducted into the Sports Hall of Fame this week, it will have been nearly 100 years since they last put on their jerseys to play.
Despite the decades that have passed, their example lives on, reminding us of the importance of sharing the invaluable lessons of sport and continuing to inspire the next generation of athletes.

Their stories show us how much progress we have made as a society - and how much we still have left to do to promote diversity and level the playing field for all athletes.Special to National PostMichael Burns is Executive Chair of Canada's Valour Games and Co-Chair, Canada's Sports Hall of Fame, 66th Order of Sport Awards.Cecile Chung is General Counsel at Samuel, Son &; Co. and Co-Chair, Canada's Sports Hall of Fame, 66th Order of Sport Award.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2022 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.
